questions.text: In the following pressure-volume loop diagram of left ventricle, the mitral valve will close at the point:
questions.solution:
The closure of the mitral valve corresponds to point 2, which marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • Point 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • Point 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • Point 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • Point 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling:  

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point 1 to point 2.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume which corresponds to about 50 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B, the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume which corresponds to about 120 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve closes.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction:

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumetric contraction lasts from point 2 to point 3.
  • At point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) and then the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point 3 to point 4.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of relaxation lasts from point 4 to point 1.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 ml of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution:
Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

Na+ channels are fast activating and are responsible for depolarization phase of action potential.

K+ channels are slow activating and open for prolonged duration than the sodium channels. They are responsible for repolarization phase of action potential. Also, the postassium channels return slowly to their closed state, which is responsible for after-hyperpolarization.

The sequence of events during the action potential occur in 7 steps as described below.

1. Resting state - Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters into the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes opening of more sodium channels through positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

questions.text: Feedback uptake of surfactant by type II alveolar epithelial cells is regulated by
questions.solution:
Feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveo­lar epithelial cell is regulated by surfactant protein type A.

Surfactant:

It is the fluid lining the alveoli. It is produced by type 2 pneumocytes. It is mainly made up of phospholipids and proteins. The majority of the phospholipid is phosphatidylcholine. The second most abundant phospholipid is phosphatidylglycerol (PG). 

The important surfactant proteins (SP) present in the surfactant are:

  • SP-A is a large glycoprotein with a collagen-like domain. It regu­lates the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveo­lar epithelial cells that secrete it.
  • SP-B and SP-C are smaller proteins. They form the film of the surfactant.
  • SP-D is a glycoprotein. It plays an important role in the organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

The important function of the surface is to reduce surface tension. The pressure required for the expansion of alveoli is directly proportional to the surface tension present over the alveolar sacs. Surfactant reduces this surface tension and thereby reduces the pressure required to expand lungs. It also prevents pulmonary edema.

Clinical correlate- Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of life and peaks at 35 weeks gestation. Deficiency of surfactant leads to respiratory distress syndrome. This is common in preterm infants.

questions.text: A model cell with three different transporters (X, Y and Z) and a resting membrane potential of -75 millivolts is shown in the given figure. Consider the intracellular and extracellular concentrations of all three ions to be typical of a normal cell. Which of the following best describe transporter Y?
questions.solution:
Secondary active transport best describes the transporter Y.

In a normal cell, intracellular concentrations of sodium, calcium, and chloride are less than the extracellular concentrations, whereas potassium has a higher intracellular concentration compared with its extracellular concentration.

The figure shows that transporter Y moves sodium down its concentration gradient into the cell and moves calcium against its concentration gradient out of the cell. The energy required to move calcium ions against their concentration gradient is supplied by the sodium concentration gradient (which was supplied by ATP) and is a typical example of secondary active transport.

Transporter X in the figure moves both potassium and sodium against their concentration gradients, requiring use of ATP at the pump, and is a example of primary active transport.

Transporter Z suggests that chloride can move in either direction across the cell membrane but only by simple diffusion through the water-filled membrane channel.

questions.text: The given image shows the strength of muscle contraction with successive stimulation. What is the cause of the phenomenon shown?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon and occurs because of increased intracellular calcium.

When a muscle begins to contract after a long period of rest, the strength of muscle contraction during each twitch increases successively with each stimulus. After this, the strength of contraction in each twitch reaches a plateau. This phenomenon is called the staircase effect or the Treppe phenomenon. It is caused primarily by the increasing calcium ions in the cytosol. Each successive muscle contraction causes more and more calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, and these ions cannot be recaptured back immediately.

As the frequency of contractions further increases, a new contraction begins to occur before the previous one is over. Thus, the second contraction is added to the first one and the strength of the contraction increases. As this phenomenon progresses, the frequency reaches a critical level and the contractions become so rapid that they fuse together into a smooth and continuous contraction. This phenomenon is known as frequency summation and tetanization (options B and C).

 

Length-tension relationship (option A) refers to the relationship between the length of the muscle fiber and the active tension that it develops. As the length of the muscle is increased, there is an increase in the active tension which develops in a muscle due to more overlapping between the actin filaments and the myosin cross-bridges. However, this increase in tension only occurs till a limit. The optimum length at which the maximum tension develops is 2.0 to 2.2 μm of length.

questions.text: In a cutaneous sensory neuron, at which of the following places is the propagated action potential generated?
questions.solution:
In cutaneous sensory neurons, propagated action potentials are generated in the initial node of Ranvier.

From a functional point of view, neurons generally have four important zones :

  1. A receptor, or dendritic zone, where multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated
  2. A site where propagated action potentials are generated (the initial segment in spinal motor neurons, the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons)
  3. An axonal process that transmits propagated impulses to the nerve endings
  4. The nerve endings, where action potentials cause the release of synaptic transmitters

The cell body is often located at the dendritic zone end of the axon, but it can be within the axon (eg, auditory neurons)

questions.text: First physiological response to high environmental temperature is:
questions.solution:
The temperature control system uses three important mechanisms to reduce body heat when the body temperature becomes too great:

  • Vasodilation of skin blood vessels. In almost all areas of the body, the skin blood vessels become intensely dilated. This is caused by inhibition of the sympathetic centers in the posterior hypothalamus that cause vasoconstriction. Full vasodilation can increase the rate of heat transfer to the skin as much as eightfold.
  • Sweating
  • Decrease in heat production. The mechanisms that cause excess heat production, such as shivering and chemical thermogenesis, are strongly inhibited.

questions.text: An elderly lady presented to the clinic following a head injury. She exhibited an unsteady drunk-like gait while entering the examination room. She also had nodding movements of the head and nystagmus. Which region of the cerebellum marked in the following image was most likely affected by the bleed?
questions.solution:
Area marked as 4 is most likely affected by the bleed, i.e., vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe).

Cerebellum has three parts based on function.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): This lobe is the oldest part of the cerebellum. It has vestibular connections concerned with equilibrium and eye movements. Therefore, in lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, patients will have gait ataxia, nodding of the head and axial body (known as titubation), and nystagmus.
  • Spinocerebellum: This is the region that receives proprioceptive inputs from the body as well as from the motor cortex. By comparing plan from the motor cortex with performance, it smoothens and coordinates movements that are ongoing.
  • Cerebrocerebellum: This is the newest part of the cerebellum. They coordinate with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements. Patients will have dysmetria, dysarthria, dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, or intention tremor in one or both extremities. 

Lesions in the cerebellum may present with the following symptoms:

  • Wide-based, drunk-like unsteady, stumbling gait, which is also called staggering gait
  • Ataxia - Defects in movement and coordination
  • Dysdiadokinesia - Inability to perform alternating movements (e.g. supination, pronation) at a fast pace
  • Dysequilibrium - Loss of balance
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor - This tremor is not present during rest, but is present during voluntary movements of limbs. The tremor increases when it reaches the target object of its movement.
  • Speech - Slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

questions.text: Which of the following changes occur if you exercise at high altitude?
questions.solution:
Rise in urinary bicarbonate level is observed if a person exercises at high altitude.

Adaptation at high Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing Respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic). This raised pH inhibits the brain stem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH towards normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is located between Sertoli cells and Sertoli cells.

Sertoli cells are linked by tight junctions, the strongest intercellular barrier in the body. This arrangement forms the blood-testes barrier.

questions.text: The Phase 2, in the ventricular myocyte action potential, shown in the image below, is due to:

choices.text: Calcium channels remaining open longer than sodium channels
Increased membrane permeability to potassium ions
Rapid inactivation of the Na+ channels

questions.solution:
Action potential: electrical stimulation created by a sequence of ion fluxes through specialized channels in the membrane (sarcolemma) of cardiomyocytes that leads to cardiac contraction.

Action potential in cardiomyocytes:

The action potential in typical cardiomyocytes is composed of 5 phases (0-4), beginning and ending with phase 4.

Phase 4: The resting phase

  1. The resting potential in a cardiomyocytes is −90 mV due to a constant outward leak of K+ through inward rectifier channels.
  2. Na+ and Ca2+ channels are closed at resting TMP.

Phase 0: Depolarization

  1. An action potential triggered in a neighbouring cardiomyocytes or pacemaker cell causes the TMP to rise above −90 mV.
  2. Fast Na+ channels start to open one by one and Na+ leaks into the cell, causing further raise in TMP.
  3. TMP approaches −70mV, the threshold potential in cardiomyocytes, i.e. the point at which enough fast Na+ channels have opened to generate a self-sustaining inward Na+ current.
  4. The large Na+ current rapidly depolarizes the TMP to 0 mV and slightly above 0 mV for a transient period of time called the overshoot;
  5. Fast Na+ channels close (recall that fast Na+ channels are time-dependent).
  6. L-type (“long-opening”) Ca2+ channels open when the TMP is greater than −40 mV and cause a small but steady influx of Ca2+ down its concentration gradient.

Phase 1: Early repolarization

  1. TMP is now slightly positive.
  2. Some K+ channels open briefly and an outward flow of K+ returns the TMP to approximately 0 mV.

Phase 2: The plateau phase

  1. L-type Ca2+ channels are still open and there is a small, constant inward current of Ca2+. This becomes significant in the excitation-contraction coupling process described below.
  2. K+ leaks out down its concentration gradient through delayed rectifier K+ channels.
  3. These two countercurrent are electrically balanced, and the TMP is maintained at a plateau just below 0 mV throughout phase 2.

Phase 3: Repolarization

  1. Ca2+ channels are gradually inactivated.
  2. Persistent outflow of K+, now exceeding Ca2+ inflow, brings TMP back towards resting potential of −90 mV to prepare the cell for a new cycle of depolarization.
  3. Normal transmembrane ionic concentration gradients are restored by returning Na+ and Ca2+ ions to the extracellular environment, and K+ ions to the cell interior.
  4. The pumps involved include the sarcolemmal Na+-Ca2+ exchanger, Ca2+-ATPase and Na+-K+-ATPase.

questions.solution:
A PET scan would show a projection of fibres from neighbouring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex.

  • In a phantom limb, cortical plasticity occurs.
  • This means that there is a projection of fibres from neighbouring areas into the cortical area previously occupied by the phantom limb.

Cortical plasticity / Phantom limb

Features :

  • A phantom limb is the sensation that an amputated or missing limb is still attached.
  • Plasticity is the ability of the brain to adapt to such a condition by reorganization of thalamic and cortical structures.
  • If a digit is amputated in a monkey, the cortical representation of the neighbouring digits spreads into the cortical area that was previously occupied by the representation of the amputated digit.
  • The converse also holds true - If the cortical area representing a digit is removed, the somatosensory map of the digit moves to the surrounding cortex.

Diagnosis and Management :

  • PET scan is used to document these plastic changes in cortex.
  • Use of epidural analgesia during amputation surgery decreases incidence of phantom pain.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about feedback control system is incorrect?

Positive feedback in a system generally promotes instability, rather than stability, and in some cases even death. For this reason, positive feedback, is often called a vicious cycle.

Feed-forward control is used to apprise the brain whether a muscle movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscle the next time the movement is required. This mechanism is often called adaptive control.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman had an autonomic neuropathy that disrupted the sympathetic nerve supply to the pupillary dilator muscle of her right eye. Denervation supersensitivity develops in the muscle after the nerve supplying it is cut. Since the nerve to her right dilator pupillae is damaged, the right eye becomes excessively sensitive to the sympathomimetic drug. So, the right eye becomes much more dilated than the left.

Denervation Supersensitivity:

  • Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where the axon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction.
  • Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletal muscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemical mediator that normally activates it.
  • This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actual nerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter stores and prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Once the drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequent release of the neurotransmitter.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with chronic heart failure presents with a particular breathing pattern. His depth and rate of respiration are plotted as given below. The type of breathing abnormality seen here is?
questions.solution:
The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. 

Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

 
In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the person ventilates excessively, leading to an excessive loss of CO2 and an increased concentration of O2 in the blood. These changes in the blood are detected only after a few seconds after the pulmonary blood reaches the brain. Thus ventilation does not get inhibited immediately.
 
When the overventilated blood finally reaches the respiratory center in the brain, the center gets excessively depressed, and ventilation is inhibited. This leads to increased CO2 and decreased O2 in the alveoli. It takes the center a few more seconds to respond to these reversed changes, leading to excessive ventilation. The cycle then repeats.
 
 
In severe chronic cardiac failure, blood flow from the lungs to the brain is slow. This leads to alveolar changes in the CO2 and O2 occurring for longer than usual and excessive storage of these gases within the alveoli and pulmonary blood. After a few seconds, the periodic respiratory drive becomes extreme and Cheyne-Stokes breathing begins. 
 
Other options:
Option A: Kussmaul's breathing is a form of hyperventilation. It occurs due to an increased tidal volume with or without an increase in respiratory rate. It is seen in association with any condition that leads to acidosis.
 
Option B: Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Option D: Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing. Blood gas concentrations are normal.

questions.text: At plasma para-aminohippuric acid (PAH) concentrations of lower than transport maximum (Tm), PAH?

choices.text: Secretion rate equals PAH excretion rate
Concentration in the renal vein is close to zero
Concentration in the renal vein equals PAH concentration in the renal artery

questions.solution:
• At plasma PAH concentrations that are lower than transport maximum (Tm), PAH concentration in the renal vein is nearly zero because the sum of filtration plus secretion removes virtually all PAH from the renal plasma.
  • Thus, the PAH concentration in the renal vein is less than that in the renal artery because most of the PAH entering the kidney is excreted in urine.
  • PAH clearance is greater than inulin clearance because PAH is filtered and secreted whereas inulin is only filtered.

Calculation of reabsorption and secretion rates:

  • The reabsorption or secretion rate is the difference between the amount filtered across the glomerular capillaries and the amount excreted in urine. 

It is calculated with the following equations:

  1. Filtered load = Glomerular Filtration Rate x Plasma Concentration
  2. Excretion rate = V (urine) x Ux
  • Where,
  • V = Urine flow rate in mL/min
  • Ux = Concentration of solute X in urine in mg/mL

3. Reabsorption rate = Filtered load – Excretion rate

4. Secretion rate = Excretion rate – Filtered load

Thus from the above equations it is clear that,

  • If the filtered load is greater than the excretion rate (FL > UV or UV/FL < 1), then the solute is reabsorbed along the tubule.
  • If excretion is greater than the filtered load (UV > FL or UV/FL > 1), then the substance is secreted by the tubule.

Transport maximum:

  • Denoted as Tm or Tmax, it refers to the point at which increases in concentration of a substance do not result in an increase in movement of a substance across a cell membrane.
  • In renal physiology, the concept of transport maximum is often discussed in the context of glucose and PAH.
  • For both substances (as with all substances), the quantity excreted can be determined with the following equation:
  • Excretion = (filtration + secretion) - reabsorption
  • The proximal convoluted tubule of the nephron has protein channels that reabsorb glucose, and others that secrete para-aminohippuric acid (PAH). However, its ability to do so is proportionate to the channel proteins available for the transport.
  • Glucose is not secreted, so excretion = filtration - reabsorption. Both filtration and reabsorption are directly proportional to the concentration of glucose in the plasma.
  • PAH is not reabsorbed and is secreted, so excretion = filtration + secretion. As with glucose, the transfer is at the proximal tubule, but in the opposite direction: from the peritubular capillaries to the lumen. At low levels, all the PAH is transferred, but at high levels, the transport maximum is reached, and the PAH takes longer to clear.

The neocortex, the amygdala, and the striatum are associated with implicit (procedural) memory, which is intact in this patient.

Related Pearl: Forms of Memory

From physiologic point of view memory is divided into explicit and implicit forms.

questions.text: A 55 kg lady has a resting oxygen consumption of 240 ml/min with 0.25 ml O2/ml of systemic arterial oxygen content and systemic mixed venous content of 0.20 ml O2/ml. Her baseline heart rate is 70 beats/min. Her cardiac output and stroke volume respectively will be:
questions.solution:
Based on the Fick principle, cardiac output can be calculated by the following equation:

Cardiac output = Oxygen consumption / [O2] pulmonary vein - [O2] pulmonary artery

In the given scenario:

  • The oxygen consumption for the whole body at rest is 240 mL/min.
  • Pulmonary vein oxygen content is measured in systemic arterial blood, which is 0.25 mL/min
  • Pulmonary artery oxygen content is measured in systemic venous blood, which is 0.20 mL/min

Hence Cardiac output = 240 ml/min / 0.25-0.20

                                = 4800 ml/min or 4.8L/min

Stroke volume = Cardiac output/Heart rate

                                          = 4800 ml/min/70 beats/min

                                          = 68.5 ml/beat

questions.text: Effect of efferent arteriole constriction on GFR is:
questions.solution:
• At moderate levels of constriction, there is a slight increase in GFR, but with severe constriction, there is a decrease in GFR.
  • Constriction of the efferent arterioles increases the resistance to outflow from the glomerular capillaries. This mechanism raises glomerular hydrostatic pressure, and as long as the increase in efferent resistance does not reduce renal blood flow too much, GFR increases slightly.
  • However, because efferent arteriolar constriction also reduces renal blood flow, the plasma protein concentration increases and hence glomerular colloid osmotic pressure increases (Donnan effect). Therefore, if constriction of efferent arterioles is severe (more than about a threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the rise in colloid osmotic pressure exceeds the increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure caused by efferent arteriolar constriction. When this situation occurs, the net force for filtration actually decreases, causing a reduction in GFR.

questions.text: A 57-year-old professor at a medical school experienced numerous episodes of a sudden loss of muscle tone and an irresistible urge to sleep in the middle of the afternoon. The diagnosis was narcolepsy. True about it is:

choices.text: Characterized by a sudden onset of NREM sleep
Has a familial incidence associated with a class II antigen of the major histocompatibility complex
Due to the presence of an excessive number of orexin-producing neurons in the hypothalamus
Is the most common cause of daytime sleepiness

questions.solution:
Narcolepsy has a familial incidence strongly associated with a class II antigen of the major histocompatibility complex on chromosome 6 at the HLA-DR2 or HLA-DQW1 locus, implying a genetic susceptibility.

  • Narcolepsy is a chronic neurologic disorder caused by the brain’s inability to regulate sleep–wake cycles normally.
  • The affected individual experiences a sudden loss of voluntary muscle tone (cataplexy), an eventual irresistible urge to sleep during daytime, and possibly brief episodes of total paralysis at the beginning or end of sleep.
  • Narcolepsy is also characterized by a sudden onset of REM sleep, unlike normal sleep that begins with NREM, slow-wave sleep.
  • Compared to brains from healthy persons, the brains of persons with narcolepsy often contain fewer hypocretin (orexin)-producing neurons in the hypothalamus.
  • The most common cause of daytime sleepiness is Obstructive Sleep Apnoea.

questions.text: Erythropoietin is produced by all of the following except ______

  • Chief function
    • Erythropoietin increases the number of erythropoietin-sensitive committed stem cells in the bone marrow that are converted to RBC precursors and subsequently to mature RBC.
  • Stimuli that increase erythropoietin secretion
    • Hypoxia (most potent)

    • Androgens
    • Alkalosis that develops in high altitude
    • Catecholamines via β adrenergic mechanism

questions.text: Which hormone is not stored in its endocrine-producing gland?

questions.text: Which of the following protein is involved in the absorption of calcium in the intestine?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male met with a road traffic accident and suffered a head injury. On examination, he was drowsy and his blood pressure is high. Which reflex is responsible for elevated blood pressure in this condition?
questions.solution:
The reflex responsible for elevated blood pressure(BP) in head injury patients is the Cushing reflex.

When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to rostral ventrolateral neurons is compromised, and the local hypoxia and hypercapnia increase the discharge of the central chemoreceptors. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure (Cushing reflex) tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Cushing reflex causes a triad of symptoms:

  • Reflex bradycardia (via arterial baroreceptors)
  • Hypertension (with widened pulse pressure)
  • Irregular respiration (bradypnea)

questions.text: Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of_____

choices.text: Increased Na + concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
Increased Cl - concentration in thick ascending loop of Henle
Increased Na + concentration in macula densa
Increased Cl- concentration in macula densa

questions.solution:
Tubuloglomerular feedback is mediated by the sensing of increased Na+ concentration in macula densa.

Macula densa are the specialized cells present at the distal end of the thick ascending loop of Henle where it reaches the glomerulus. Distal convoluted tubule starts from macula densa. Macula forms part of the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

While both Na+ and Cl- are delivered to the macula densa cells, it is the increased concentration of Na+ in the cells that increases the Na+-K ATPase activity leading to the feedback.

questions.text: Hering-Breuer reflexes are mediated by ____________ .
questions.solution:
Hering-Breuer reflexes are mediated by slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers.

Hering-Breuer inflation reflex: "Prolonged inspiration inhibits further inspiration"

  • Hyperinflation of lungs stimulates slowly adapting pulmonary stretch receptors and the impulses travel in the vagus nerve via large myelinated fibers.
  • This signal inhibits the inspiratory ramp signals of the dorsal respiratory group of neurons (DRG), thus, inspiration is quickly inhibited and expiration follows.
  • Advantages of Hering-Breuer inflation reflex: It cuts down the inspiration time, and therefore,
    • It prevents overinflation of the lungs.
    • Lungs operate at lower lung volumes, thereby preventing wastage of energy.
  • The Hering-Breuer reflex is activated when the lung volume increases to more than three times the normal tidal volume (tidal volume = 0.5 liters/breath; So, lung volume > 1.5 liters per breath activates the reflex).
  • It signifies that the reflex plays a protective role preventing the overinflation of the lung rather than regulating the normal ventilation.

questions.solution:

NO and VIP are released by neurons in the anterograde direction from the bolus which produces relaxation in front of the stimulus.

questions.text: Which among the following does the graph given below depict?
questions.solution:
The graph given above depicts the Haldane effect.

The binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This is known as the Haldane effect. It helps in the transport of CO2 from the tissues to the lungs. The graph shows small portions of two CO2 dissociation curves:

  • When the PO2 is 100 mm Hg, which is the case in the blood capillaries of the lungs.
  • When the PO2 is 40 mm Hg, which is the case in the tissue capillaries.

At the normal PCO2 of 45 mm Hg in the tissues represented by point A, 52 volume percent of CO2 combines with the blood. Upon entering the lungs, the PCO2 falls to 40 mm Hg and the PO2 rises to 100 mm Hg. The increase in PO2 shifts the CO2 dissociation curve from the top curve to the lower curve, so the CO2 content falls to point B.

Thus, the Haldane effect approximately doubles the amount of CO2 released from the blood in the lungs and the amount picked up by the tissues.

(Remember - HaLdane effect occurs in Lungs and causes Left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve)

Other options:

Option A: Bohr effect: A right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve in response to an increase in blood CO2 and hydrogen ions, enhances the release of O2 from the blood in the tissues. This enhances the oxygenation of the blood in the lungs.

Option B: Henry's Law in Respiration: The amount of oxygen that dissolves into the bloodstream is directly proportional to the partial pressure of oxygen in alveolar air.

Option D: Boyle's Law: The pressure of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume if its temperature is kept constant.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and decreased urinary phosphate excretion. The injection​ of parathyroid hormone (PTH) causes an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP). The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hypoparathyroidism after thyroid surgery.

Low blood Ca2+ and high blood phosphate are consistent with hypoparathyroidism.

Lack of parathyroid hormone (PTH) decreases bone resorption, decreases renal reabsorption of Ca2+, and increases renal reabsorption of phosphate (causing low urinary phosphate).

Because the patient responded to exogenous PTH with an increase in urinary cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP), the G protein coupling the PTH receptor to adenylate cyclase is apparently normal. Consequently, pseudohypoparathyroidism is excluded.

Vitamin D intoxication would cause hypercalcemia, not hypocalcemia, while Vitamin D deficiency would cause hypocalcemia and hypophosphatemia.

Hypoparathyroidism: It is most commonly a result of thyroid surgery, or it is congenital.

It is characterized by the following:

  • Decreased serum Ca2+ (hypocalcemia) and tetany
  • Increased serum phosphate (hyperphosphatemia)
  • Decreased urinary phosphate excretion

questions.text: The negative feedback control of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) secretion is regulated by which of the following functions of the Sertoli cells?
questions.solution:
Inhibin synthesized by Sertoli cells inhibits the release of FSH from the anterior pituitary.

The male hypothalamic-pituitary axis is regulated by negative feedback through two mechanisms. First, testosterone inhibits the secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus and LH from the anterior pituitary, reducing the frequency and amplitude of GnRH pulses. Second, Sertoli cells produce inhibin, a glycoprotein that inhibits FSH secretion by the anterior pituitary. Thus, Sertoli cells regulate spermatogenesis by producing inhibin, which acts as a marker of spermatogenic activity.

Other options:

Option B and C: Testosterone is aromatized in the ovaries in women. Additionally, it only inhibits the release of LH from the anterior pituitary not FSH.

Option D: Tight junctions between adjacent Sertoli cells near the basal lamina form a blood-testis barrier that prevents many large molecules from passing from the interstitial tissue. However, this has no role to play in the inhibition of FSH secretion.
